newsArray.content: THE ASHES series is finally here as England and Australia do battle! All eyes are on the Gabba tonight as the First Test of the series kicks off. Though star bowler Jimmy Anderson will play no part for England, after pulling out with a calf injury. newsArray.full_description: THE ASHES series is finally here as England and Australia do battle! All eyes are on the Gabba tonight as the First Test of the series kicks off. Though star bowler Jimmy Anderson will play no part for England, after pulling out with a calf injury. Anderson, 39, will be kept on ice for at least the day-night second Test at Adelaide on December 16. He is at his most dangerous using a pink ball under floodlights so England do not consider his absence a disaster. Ollie Pope is preferred to Jonny Bairstow in the 12-man squad while spinner Jack Leach is included as is Ben Stokes. JOIN SUN VEGAS: GET A FREE Â£10 BONUS WITH 100s OF GAMES TO PLAY AND NO DEPOSIT REQUIRED (Ts&Cs apply) Follow ALL of the latest updates below... SCHEDULE The toss is a few minutes away but for those that want to plan their winter around watching cricket in the small hours, hereâ€™s the full series schedule. The fifth Test will not be played in Perth due to Covid quarantine restrictions in Western Australia with a new venue to be announced soon. Share your #Ashes setup... Where are you following from? ğŸŒ What are you drinking? â˜• What are you eating? ğŸ½ JOHN ETHERIDGE REPORTS: Former Aussie skipper Ricky Ponting, a pundit for Channel 7's coverage in Australia, believes England are covering up a Jimmy Anderson injury. England insist Anderson is 100 per cent fit and does not have a calf problem. But Ponting said: "I'm not buying that - there's no way England would choose to leave out their best bowler in the First Test of an Ashes series if he didn't have some sort of injury." BUILDING BLOCKS Englandâ€™s preparation on the field has been far from ideal â€“ to say the least. Both warm-up games in Brisbane have been heavily affected by rain, meaning Joe Rootâ€™s men are short on time in the middle headed into this series. And England were further rocked by the news yesterday that Jimmy Anderson is all but out of this Test match with a calf injury. Itâ€™s going to be a tall order without the leader of the attack. But Stokes is back and that Aussie batting line-up can be flaky. TRIBUTE SunSport cricket correspondent John Etheridge is Down Under this winter. He has some sad news about a former England cricketer... " England will wear black armbands today in memory former England womenâ€™s cricketer Eileen Ash, who sadly passed away earlier this week aged 110. " She was the worldâ€™s oldest Test cricketer, making her debut in 1937 ." CRICKET SCANDALS English cricket has been rocked in recent months by the Azeem Rafiq racism scandal at Yorkshire and the reverberations are still being felt. Australia have their own problems as well entering the series after captain Tim Paine stepped down and pulled out over historic texts sent to a female colleague. Itâ€™s been a bumpy ride for the sport and it really needs a riveting contest on the pitch between two bitter rivals for the most coveted of prizes to start to shift the focus. WELCOME Itâ€™s finally time! Good evening everyone, welcome along to our LIVE coverage of the first Ashes Test in Brisbane. The talking is almost over as Joe Rootâ€™s men embark on their quest to wrestle back the coveted Ashes urn from their biggest rivals down under. Itâ€™s been a tough build-up for many reasons, but weâ€™re almost set to get the five-Test battle underway at The Gabba. Australia have historically been excellent at their Queensland fortress, but their last Test match here ended in a quite remarkable defeat in January. The Gabba walls were breached by India in a brilliant victory to seal the series, and England will be looking to inflict further pain on an ailing Aussie Test team. Play begins at midnight UK time â€“ the toss will be coming up at 11.30pm, at which point weâ€™ll see Englandâ€™s line-up. Hope youâ€™ve got plenty of coffee and snacks ready because itâ€™s going to be a longggg night.

newsArray.title: Jimmy Anderson has hunger to play beyond age of 40â€¦ because he is so GRUMPY, says England team-mate Jos Buttler

newsArray.description: JOS BUTTLER knows Jimmy Anderson has the hunger to play beyond the age of 40 â€” because he is so grumpy. Despite Anderson being omitted from the Ashes opener, Buttler is convinced Englandâ€™s swing king has no intention of retiring. Anderson turns 40 next July but Buttler reckons he wants to continue for as long as [â€¦]
newsArray.content: JOS BUTTLER knows Jimmy Anderson has the hunger to play beyond the age of 40 â€” because he is so grumpy. Despite Anderson being omitted from the Ashes opener, Buttler is convinced Englandâ€™s swing king has no intention of retiring. Jimmy Anderson is being rested for the Ashes opener Anderson turns 40 next July but Buttler reckons he wants to continue for as long as possible. He explained: â€œIt seems that age is just a number for Jimmy. â€œHeâ€™s in fantastic shape, his skills are as brilliant as ever and he still seems to be trying to improve and learn new things. â€œThat hunger doesnâ€™t seem to be wavering at all. â€œHe still gets just as grumpy if he bowls a bad ball â€” and that competitiveness is incredibly high in anything he does, let alone on a cricket field. â€œI see him wanting to continue as long as he can and there doesnâ€™t feel like thereâ€™s anything in the way of him doing that at the moment.â€ Most read in Sport BOO HOO LU Luis Suarez in tears after being forced off in Atletico Madrid's must-win clash 'MISINTERPRETED' Lewandowski denies Messi Ballon d'Or rift after 'empty words' claims VAN DE START How Man Utd could line-up vs Young Boys with Van de Beek & Henderson CONFIRMED HE'S A KEEPER Ajax 'want to sign Man Utd keeper Dean Henderson on loan in January' NEW LOOK How Newcastle could line up after January transfer window with Trippier & Witsel JANUARY SALES Tottenham pair Bergwijn and Rodon set to leave in January transfer window Anderson was left out of the first Test even though England insisted he was fit to play. Captain Joe Root and head coach Chris Silverwood wanted to eliminate any chance of Anderson not being 100 per cent for the day-night second Test in Adelaide on December 16. Englandâ€™s record Test bowler, with 632 wickets, is potentially deadly under lights and the fifth Test will now also be played with a pink ball at either Melbourne, Sydney or Hobart. After the game was shifted from Perth, the venue will be put out to tender as Cricket Australia attempt to recoup some cash. England remember the 2019 Ashes when Anderson bowled four overs in the first Test at Edgbaston before limping off with a calf injury and he was not seen again in the series. PAJos Buttler is set to feature in his first Ashes series in Australia[/caption] The teamâ€™s rain-interrupted preparations here meant Anderson and the other bowlers were short of overs, making an injury more possible. An England spokesman said: â€œJimmy was fit to play. With five Tests in six weeks, the plan was to get him ready for Adelaide. â€œWith the limited build-up we had, both he and the management didnâ€™t want to take the risk of him playing after what had happened in 2019 at Edgbaston.â€ Wicketkeeper Buttler, 31, added: â€œJimmy could have played but itâ€™s a long series and we want a guy like that to be available to play as much of a part as possible.â€

newsArray.title: Ashes 2021-22: Australia v England first Test, day one â€“ live!
creator: Geoff Lemon at the Gabba (now) and Tanya Aldred (later)
newsArray.description: First ball at the Gabba in Brisbane at 11am AEDT, 12am GMTThe Spin: sign up and receive our free cricket newsletterAny thoughts? Email Geoff or tweet @GeoffLemonSportGood morning from Brisbane! I happen to know that it is already late at night in the UK, and any other number of times in other zones around the world, but here from the Gabba it is a fresh new day with a fresh new pitch in the middle.The Ashes! That old thing. Thank providence that it is beginning, so that I donâ€™t have to write, nor do you have to read, any more preview pieces. From now on, we will have views and reviews only. Continue reading...
newsArray.full_description: Greg Bradley emails in. â€œHave a great Ashes series or at least have a great Ashes first test, or maybe first innings, or maybe first morning ? Lovely to see your intro but the stadium is empty. No crowd ? Weird. Iâ€™ve gotten used to crowds at the footie again.â€ Well, the crowd is coming in. Still almost an hour until play. Itâ€™s allegedly a sell-out today. The Gabba can take over 40,000. How about the pitch? It looks green, yes. But the Gabba pitch always looks green on day one. Itâ€™s not usually grass that does a whole lot. Iâ€™m willing to bet it will be very decent batting surface, after perhaps a little hard work early. The big question: will we get play? Well, probably. The forecast for Brisbane entire says that rain may be around from exactly 10am local time, which is the first ball. But that doesnâ€™t mean it will fall here at 10am. There are thunderstorms forecast for the afternoon, but hopefully that means they will rain intensely but briefly and then clear off. The Gabba drains better than any other ground in the world, and weâ€™ve seen the ground staff here perform miracles before. So, be optimistic. Good morning from Brisbane! I happen to know that it is already late at night in the UK, and any other number of times in other zones around the world, but here from the Gabba it is a fresh new day with a fresh new pitch in the middle. The Ashes! That old thing. Thank providence that it is beginning, so that I donâ€™t have to write, nor do you have to read, any more preview pieces. From now on, we will have views and reviews only. Everyone is out there on the ground: players, whole squads, coaches, umpires, ground staff, tractors, camera operators. Thereâ€™s Haseeb Hameed with a bat under each arm, just in case. Cap backwards. Strutting. Thereâ€™s Danny Reuben, talking media with the Channel Seven broadcast managers. Mike Hussey is out there in a suit, Adam Gilchrist in shirt sleeves. There are nets strung up for throw-downs. Eskies full of drinks. Hurdles and medicine balls. A circle of England players are heading a football around. There are strings of orange flags around the centre square. David Warner is standing on the centre wicket about where the stumps will go in, facing up with his bat and visualising. Itâ€™s warm, itâ€™s sweaty, itâ€™s overcast, and itâ€™s happening. Iâ€™m Geoff, hello.

newsArray.title: 'Annoyed' great rips 'ridiculous' cricket change
creator: wwos
newsArray.description: Mitchell Johnson has aired frustration over the crackdown on confrontation in cricket in recent years, as the Ashes loom.
newsArray.content: When Mitchell Johnson is asked about his intense confrontation with a young Ben Stokes on the fourth day of the 2013 Adelaide Test, it doesn't take long for the former superstar fast bowler to grumble about an "absolute crap" change to cricket.Johnson was famously white-hot during the 2013-14 Ashes, snaring 37 wickets at an average of 13.97 and a strike-rate of 30.5 to lead Australia to a 5-0 whitewash.Stokes, 22 and on Test debut, was dealt a dose of Johnson's ferocity when the two collided on the pitch during the final session of day four in Adelaide. As the redhead scampered through for a run, Johnson held his ground on his follow-through and the two men clashed. A staring contest ensued, prompting umpire Kumar Dharmasena to plant himself between the pair and usher Johnson away.READ MORE: The Ashes 2021-22 Ultimate GuideJohnson and Stokes were charged by the umpires but the International Cricket Committee opted against taking disciplinary action."At first it's like, 'Ah, hang on a minute. What's this young debutant doing?'," Johnson recalls in an interview with Wide World of Sports on the cusp of the 2021-22 Ashes."But then you're like, 'Nah, this awesome, he's on here, he wants it, you can tell, you can sense it, you can see it'."It was then that Johnson began to air his frustration, revealing he objects to officials trying to police argy-bargy, deadly stares and sledging out of the game."People want to see a bit of heart," Johnson says."There are obviously lines that you don't cross ... (but) I think that should still be part of the game."I get annoyed.READ MORE: Former Poms destroyer shreds Root's Gabba claim"That happened towards the back end of my career. You'd follow through and umpires were like, 'Get back to your mark, don't involve yourself in staring at a player'. And I'd be like, 'What do you mean? I'm not doing anything; I'm staring at a player'. It's a whole part of my body language. It helps me play the game."It happens with the batters, as well, if they were to come down and say something."I just think it's ridiculous. It really is."READ MORE: Injury blow for England with James Anderson ruled outCricket's technology boomed throughout Johnson's career.Hot Spot (2006), DRS (2008) and LED stumps and bails (2012), more commonly referred to as 'zing bails', were all introduced during Johnson's 256-match international career spanning 2005 to 2012.Hawk-Eye was introduced five months before the left-armer made his Sheffield Shield debut, in a match between Queensland and Western Australia in November 2001.Johnson's reason for the crackdown on fervid on-field antics is the use of stump microphones, introduced in Kerry Packer's World Series Cricket in 1977.Sledges made over the first 100 years of international cricket, Johnson argues, were much worse than those of today.READ MORE: WA hits out at Ashes Test snub"The thing is, if you have a look back in the history of the game, there would be worse sledges going around. But we have all the stump mics (now), we have everything going on," Johnson says."So sledging-wise, it's harmless. It really is harmless. It's about trying to take the batsman off their game. You may have heard something in the paper with a certain player, like Joe Root, working on something. So you just get into his head about that. That's what the guys around him would do, as well, like the 'keeper and the slips. They might be saying something like, 'He's working on trying to get his front foot across more'. Little things like that. It's really not that bad."The TV crews would love it when you get face to face with a batsman. You've just bounced them and you give them a bit of a stare. You're in their face a little bit, but then you move on ... It really is harmless."I've just never understood why it's changed and I don't know where it's come from."READ MORE: Lando Norris fumes at 'stupid' Formula 1Fresh in the minds of cricket fans is the sledging Tim Paine fired at Ravichandran Ashwin late on day five of this year's SCG Test.Perhaps the spiciest line of the tirade was Paine's: "At least my teammates like me, d--khead".The comments of the former Test captain led to outcry."It is crap, it is absolute crap," Johnson says."It's frustrating ... I just think it's ridiculous that people blew up about that."I definitely am passionate about sledging and confrontation and that sort of stuff, and I think it's part of the game."For a daily dose of the best of the breaking news and exclusive content from Wide World of Sports, subscribe to our newsletter by clicking here!
newsArray.full_description: When Mitchell Johnson is asked about his intense confrontation with a young Ben Stokes on the fourth day of the 2013 Adelaide Test, it doesn't take long for the former superstar fast bowler to grumble about an "absolute crap" change to cricket. Johnson was famously white-hot during the 2013-14 Ashes, snaring 37 wickets at an average of 13.97 and a strike-rate of 30.5 to lead Australia to a 5-0 whitewash. Stokes, 22 and on Test debut, was dealt a dose of Johnson's ferocity when the two collided on the pitch during the final session of day four in Adelaide. As the redhead scampered through for a run, Johnson held his ground on his follow-through and the two men clashed. A staring contest ensued, prompting umpire Kumar Dharmasena to plant himself between the pair and usher Johnson away. READ MORE: The Ashes 2021-22 Ultimate Guide Johnson and Stokes were charged by the umpires but the International Cricket Committee opted against taking disciplinary action. "At first it's like, 'Ah, hang on a minute. What's this young debutant doing?'," Johnson recalls in an interview with Wide World of Sports on the cusp of the 2021-22 Ashes. "But then you're like, 'Nah, this awesome, he's on here, he wants it, you can tell, you can sense it, you can see it'." It was then that Johnson began to air his frustration, revealing he objects to officials trying to police argy-bargy, deadly stares and sledging out of the game. "People want to see a bit of heart," Johnson says. "There are obviously lines that you don't cross ... (but) I think that should still be part of the game. "I get annoyed. READ MORE: Former Poms destroyer shreds Root's Gabba claim "That happened towards the back end of my career. You'd follow through and umpires were like, 'Get back to your mark, don't involve yourself in staring at a player'. And I'd be like, 'What do you mean? I'm not doing anything; I'm staring at a player'. It's a whole part of my body language. It helps me play the game. "It happens with the batters, as well, if they were to come down and say something. "I just think it's ridiculous. It really is." READ MORE: Injury blow for England with James Anderson ruled out Cricket's technology boomed throughout Johnson's career. Hot Spot (2006), DRS (2008) and LED stumps and bails (2012), more commonly referred to as 'zing bails', were all introduced during Johnson's 256-match international career spanning 2005 to 2012. Hawk-Eye was introduced five months before the left-armer made his Sheffield Shield debut, in a match between Queensland and Western Australia in November 2001. Johnson's reason for the crackdown on fervid on-field antics is the use of stump microphones, introduced in Kerry Packer's World Series Cricket in 1977. Sledges made over the first 100 years of international cricket, Johnson argues, were much worse than those of today. READ MORE: WA hits out at Ashes Test snub "The thing is, if you have a look back in the history of the game, there would be worse sledges going around. But we have all the stump mics (now), we have everything going on," Johnson says. "So sledging-wise, it's harmless. It really is harmless. It's about trying to take the batsman off their game. You may have heard something in the paper with a certain player, like Joe Root , working on something. So you just get into his head about that. That's what the guys around him would do, as well, like the 'keeper and the slips. They might be saying something like, 'He's working on trying to get his front foot across more'. Little things like that. It's really not that bad. "The TV crews would love it when you get face to face with a batsman. You've just bounced them and you give them a bit of a stare. You're in their face a little bit, but then you move on ... It really is harmless. "I've just never understood why it's changed and I don't know where it's come from." READ MORE: Lando Norris fumes at 'stupid' Formula 1 Fresh in the minds of cricket fans is the sledging Tim Paine fired at Ravichandran Ashwin late on day five of this year's SCG Test . Perhaps the spiciest line of the tirade was Paine 's: "At least my teammates like me, d--khead". The comments of the former Test captain led to outcry. "It is crap, it is absolute crap," Johnson says. "It's frustrating ... I just think it's ridiculous that people blew up about that. "I definitely am passionate about sledging and confrontation and that sort of stuff, and I think it's part of the game." For a daily dose of the best of the breaking news and exclusive content from Wide World of Sports, subscribe to our newsletter by clicking here!

newsArray.title: Girlfriend sledge the best Leeâ€™s ever heard
newsArray.description: Australian cricket great Brett Lee has revealed the â€œbest sledge (he) ever heardâ€ as he opened up on the role of banter in the game.
newsArray.full_description: Australian cricket great Brett Lee has revealed the â€œbest sledge (he) ever heardâ€ as he opened up on the role of banter in the game. The former quick took 310 Test wickets and claimed 380 ODI scalps across a successful international career, establishing himself as one of the fastest bowlers world cricket has ever seen. Sportâ€™s greatest rivalry is just around the corner and you can catch the Ashes live and ad-break free during play. New to Kayo? Start your free trial today > While Lee admitted sledging was part of Test cricket and the Barmy Army even wrote a song about him, the best on-field barb he heard during his playing days came from an unlikely source. â€œI reckon the best sledge Iâ€™ve ever heard was at a grade game actually, in Sydney grade cricket,â€ Lee told news.com.auâ€™s Iâ€™ve Got News For You podcast. â€œItâ€™s one of those days. Rainâ€™s falling, youâ€™re on, youâ€™re off (the field) type of thing. You canâ€™t find any momentum. â€œSo someone in our first grade team said, â€˜Letâ€™s come up with what we believe is the ugliest cricketer in Australian cricket currentlyâ€™, whether itâ€™s first-class cricket or even grade cricket. â€œSo weâ€™re going through what we thought was our ugliest XI. Anyway, we get back on, batsman comes out, takes centre, heâ€™s scratching his crease. â€œMy mate at first slip goes, â€˜Hey champ, weâ€™ve just come up with out ugliest XI and mate, looking at you right now through your lid, you are captain of the ugly XIâ€™. â€œHe turned around and said, â€˜Oh really? Well I can see your missus on the hill mate and sheâ€™s batting threeâ€™. â€œTrue story. Itâ€™s quick, itâ€™s brilliant.â€ Lee believes the best sledges are spontaneous and always make the person theyâ€™re aimed at laugh. â€œItâ€™s got to be off the cuff,â€ he said. â€œSledgingâ€™s got to come from the heart. Itâ€™s got to be quick-witted. Itâ€™s got to be spur of the moment. â€œIn all honesty, the thing with sledging is that 99.999 per cent of the time, thereâ€™s nothing untoward. You donâ€™t racially vilify someone, you donâ€™t swear so the kids at home are listening in. â€œItâ€™s always funny stuff. You sledge someone to try and put them off their game. Itâ€™s got to be fun. â€œWe arenâ€™t robots. You know the line you canâ€™t cross. If you cross it, you have to pay the consequences but most times itâ€™s fun and it actually makes the batsman or the bowler laugh, thatâ€™s the whole objective at the end.â€ Lee also revealed the time he was the butt of a practical joke in the Australian dressing room before his Test debut. â€œIt involved Adam Gilchrist and Glenn McGrath,â€ he said on Iâ€™ve Got News For You . â€œIâ€™m super nervous, playing my first Test, super anxious to get out there. Gilly is just eyeballing me saying, â€˜Just go out there, youâ€™ve done all the hard work. Just enjoy yourselfâ€™. â€œIâ€™m listening going, â€˜Yepâ€™, trying to take it all in, not knowing that as heâ€™s keeping eye contact someone was down beside me. McGrath tied my shoelaces together. â€œI got up and nearly tripped over. It was almost like, â€˜Welcomeâ€™. That was like the initiation into the Australian cricket team.â€ Listen to the Iâ€™ve Got News For You podcast here , or search for it wherever you listen to podcasts Lee will be part of Fox Cricketâ€™s commentary team for the Ashes, which begin today with the first Test at the Gabba. He is also hosting a new podcast in partnership with news.com.au, called The Brett Lee Podcast , with friend and former NSW cricketer Brad McNamara, who he describes as â€œone of the funniest guys youâ€™ll meetâ€. â€œItâ€™s a podcast about the Ashes,â€ Lee said. â€œIt involves cricket, itâ€™s not all about cricket. We cover the big topics, the news, all the different headlines that are happening in the last 24-48 hours. â€œWe get some musicians on, we get some different talent from around the world. â€œItâ€™s a combination of cricket, sport in general but also different walks of life. â€œWe both love music, both play in a band together. So we try to have a bit of fun with it as well.â€ New Australian captain Pat Cummins has spoken about the ugly sledging which has dominated past Ashes series and where he stands on it this time around. LIVE BUILD UP WA is still seething about being stripped of its Ashes Test and now it has taken aim at Cricket Australiaâ€™s handling of the situation. Cricket fans lost their minds after a youngster took a stunning catch in the Big Bash many are already calling one of the best ever.

newsArray.title: BUB vs JAR Dream11 Prediction: Fantasy Cricket Tips, Today's Playing 11 and Pitch Report for Bengal Inter District T20 2021, Match 31
creator: Anjishnu Roy
newsArray.full_description: Burdwan Blues will take on Jalpaiguri Rhinoceros in the 31st match of the Bengal Inter District T20 2021 at the Bengal Cricket Academy Ground in Kalyani on Wednesday. Both Burdwan Blues and Jalpaiguri Rhinoceros have played just a single match so far as all their other games got abandoned due to rain. Weather conditions are likely to have a major say in this match too. Jalpaiguri Rhinoceros won their only match in the competition while Burdwan Blues ended up losing their first game. BUB XI Abhisek Banerjee (c), Arnab Ghosh (wk), Abhijeet Bhagat, Arikta Das, Debapriya Ghosh, Akashdip Ghosh, Azaz Ansari, Arka Sarkar, Meraj Ansari, Bhupinder Singh, Sanjiv Kumar Singh JAR XI Surajit Roy, Abhijit Biswas, Debi Prasad Roy, Biswajit Dey, Avidipta Bose, Raman Chhetri (wk), Shirshendu Sarkar (c), Mukul Roy, Sagnik, Dhiraj Kumar Pandey, Animesh Adhikari BUB vs JAR, Bengal Inter District T20 2021, Match 31 Date and Time: December 8, 2021, 8:45 AM IST Venue: Bengal Cricket Academy Ground, Kalyani The surface has become more balanced over the last few games and both bowlers and batters will find equal assistance. As mentioned before, rain could play a pivotal role in this game too and winning the toss might prove to be crucial. Indiaâ€™s star with the bat during the second Test match against New Zealand at the Wankhede Stadium, Mumbai- Mayank Agarwal has joined the elite list of cricketers having scored a century at the iconicâ€¦ The post â€œAsk them to spell my name correctly brotherâ€: Kevin Pietersen replies hilariously to Mayank Agarwal as he shares his name at Wankhede stadium honourâ€™s board appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Kevin Pietersen replies hilariously to Mayank Agarwal after latter shares his name at Wankhede Stadiumâ€™s honourâ€™s board upon hitting a ton. Indiaâ€™s star with the bat during the second Test match against New Zealand at the Wankhede Stadium, Mumbai- Mayank Agarwal has joined the elite list of cricketers having scored a century at the iconic venue. His scores of 150 off 311 deliveries and 62 off 108 deliveries in first and second innings respectively at a wicket which had significant purchase for both the pacers and spinners, was instrumental in India winning their record 14th consecutive series victory at home- by defeating New Zealand by 372 runs- their biggest ever in terms of runs. Agarwal hence, on Tuesday, took to his social media handle to share his name inscribed at the Honourâ€™s board of the Wankhede stadium, which includes some prominent giants of the game like Sachin Tendulkar, Virender Sehwag, Rahul Dravid, and the former England batter Kevin Pietersen. Kevin Pietersen replies hilariously to Mayank Agarwal Agarwal posted a picture of himself looking at the list of players with which he shares the record with, at his social media handle. â€œThis isnâ€™t just a name on a board. This is all the hardwork culminating into something that goes beyond. Playing Test cricket and contributing to a win for your country is everything for someone who grew up worshipping the game. Itâ€™s an honour to be named alongside so many greats,â€ wrote Mayank as the caption to his picture. The list, which also included Kevin Pietersenâ€™s name was apparently spelled wrong by the authority concerned at the Wankhede. The name read â€˜K P Pietersonâ€™ instead of â€˜K P Pietersenâ€™. The 41-yeR-old was quick to notice the error on the board, and hilariously replied to Mayankâ€™s post, requesting them to spell his name correctly. This isnâ€™t just a name on a board. This is all the hardwork culminating into something that goes beyond. Playing Test cricket and contributing to a win for your country is everything for someone who grew up worshipping the game. Itâ€™s an honour to be named alongside so many greats pic.twitter.com/Z8rzIfr0X3 â€” Mayank Agarwal (@mayankcricket) December 7, 2021 Please ask them to spell my name correctly brother! â€” Kevin Pietersen (@KP24) December 7, 2021 Pietersen had smashed a total of 186 runs in the first innings against India during Englandâ€™s second Test match at Wankhede in November 2012. Courtesy his innings, England had decimated India by 10 wickets in the match, and later even went on to win the series 2-1 in the four-match Test series. Â  Â  The post â€œAsk them to spell my name correctly brotherâ€: Kevin Pietersen replies hilariously to Mayank Agarwal as he shares his name at Wankhede stadium honourâ€™s board appeared first on The SportsRush.

newsArray.title: Ashes 2021-22 venues: Full list of venues where Ashes 2021-22 Test will be played
creator: Gurpreet Singh
newsArray.description: Ashes 2021-22 venues: The first Ashes 2021-22 Test between Australia and England would take place at the Gabba from December 8. After being in the headlines for all the non-Cricketing and deplorable issues, the England and Australian Cricket teams are all set to do what they know best, as they lock horns against each otherâ€¦ The post Ashes 2021-22 venues: Full list of venues where Ashes 2021-22 Test will be played appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Ashes 2021-22 venues: The first Ashes 2021-22 Test between Australia and England would take place at the Gabba from December 8. After being in the headlines for all the non-Cricketing and deplorable issues, the England and Australian Cricket teams are all set to do what they know best, as they lock horns against each other in the first of the five-match Ashes Test series at The Gabba in Brisbane from December 8. Be it the racism scandal or the Tim Paine debacle, the build up to the Ashes 2021-22 was not how it used to be in the past, with plenty of character laundry tasks to care of before talking Cricket. But, finally the fans and experts and perhaps the players as well, are ready to focus on the business- a two-handed firm grab at the coveted Ashes urn. Last time England had won a Test match in Australia was way back in 2011-12 under the then skipper Andrew Strauss. The English side has not won a Test in Brisbane (the venue for the first Test) since 1986-87. But, they would take solace and confidence from the fact that the Gabba-ttoir (as they say it) no longer remains an impenetrable fortress it once was for the visiting teams after India finally broke the 32-year, 29-match drought in January this year. Also, England skipper Joe Root will find himself on the right side of history as he is set to become the first-ever captain to lead England in two away Ashes series. On the other hand, team Australia under a new skipper Pat Cummins would continue with its bid to once again retain the sacred Ashes urn. Talking about their stats in a nutshell, the team hasnâ€™t played a Test for 11 months, nor won an away tour since 2016, with mere four victories in their last 15 away trips. At home, they had to endure back-to-back unprecedented series losses against India in successive years. Australia and England. Itâ€™s more than just a game. Itâ€™s more than just a series. Itâ€™s the Ashes. pic.twitter.com/ytE8kxoXVB â€” 7Cricket (@7Cricket) December 7, 2021 Ashes 2021-22 venues The venues for the month long event, had to be a point of contention given the omnipresent existence of the Coronavirus across the globe. The emergence of the new COVID-19 variant in Omicron- which is gradually spreading its clan in all parts of the globe, has forced travel restrictions once again in the affected places. While the the Ashes 2021-22 venues for the first four Tests have been confirmed, the venue of the fifth Ashes Test is yet to be confirmed by the Australian Cricket board. Cricket Australia has confirmed the fifth Ashes Test wonâ€™t be staged in Perth as originally scheduled due to Western Australiaâ€™s stringent COVID-19 travel restrictions, but a decision on where the potential series decider will be played is yet to be finalized. The emergence of the virusâ€™ new Omicron variant last month, had further forced Western Australiaâ€™s Premier Mark McGowan to harden the stateâ€™s stance on quarantine rules on arrivals from New South Wales (venue of 4th Test). Under those protocols, players, their families, as well as match and broadcast staff travelling to Perth after completion of the fourth Test in Sydney (January 5-9) would be required to complete 14 days quarantine upon arrival in Western Australia. While the first Test will be played at the Gabba, Brisbane, the second Test would take place at the Adelaide Oval from December 16-20. The third (December 26-30) and the fourth (January 5-9) Test would take place at the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG) and Sydney Cricket Ground (SCG) respectively. Hobartâ€™s Blundstone Arena and the Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG) are the two potential venues, one of which would in all probability host the final Ashes Test from January 14-18. First Test: 8-12 December 2021, The Gabba (Brisbane) Second Test (D/N): 16-20 December 2021, Adelaide Oval (Adelaide) Third Test: 26-30 December 2021, MCG (Melbourne) Fourth Test: 5-9 January 2022, SCG (Sydney) Fifth Test: 16-20 January 2022, TBA. Â  The post Ashes 2021-22 venues: Full list of venues where Ashes 2021-22 Test will be played appeared first on The SportsRush.

Australia will take on England in a bid to once again retain the sacred Ashes urn, with the first Test to commence from December 8 at The Gabba in Brisbane. As far as the statistics are concerned, Team England have plenty to ponder upon as both the history and numbers arenâ€™t smiling at them with conviction at all. Last time England had won a Test match in Australia was way back in 2011-12 under the then skipper Andrew Strauss. The English side has not won a Test in Brisbane (the venue for the first Test) since 1986-87. But, they would take solace and confidence from the fact that the Gabba-ttoir (as they say it) no longer remains an impenetrable fortress it once was for the visiting teams after India finally broke the 32-year, 29-match drought in January this year. Also, England skipper Joe Root will find himself on the right side of history as he is set to become the first-ever captain to lead England in two away Ashes series. Which captain will hold this trophy at the end of the series? #Ashes pic.twitter.com/4RJdPKFbgk â€” England Cricket (@englandcricket) December 7, 2021 On the other hand, team Australia under a new skipper Pat Cummins have been in the news for all the non-Cricketing reasons off-late, with their confidence not as high as it should be for a home side. Talk about their stats in a nutshell, the team hasnâ€™t played for 11 months, nor won an away tour since 2016, with mere four victories in their last 15 away trips. At home, they had to endure back-to-back unprecedented series losses against India in successive years. Talking about the broadcast voices, which form an imperative part of the viewersâ€™ experience especially in series like the Ashes, Australiaâ€™s renowned broadcaster- Fox Sports will yet again accumulate some of the greatest names in the Cricketing world, as part of their commentating panel. Australia vs England Ashes 2021 commentators Alongside some giant names in Australiaâ€™s rich Cricketing history, former England skipper Michael Vaughan would also be providing his services in the commentary panel at a time when he has been in the headlines relating the Azeem Rafiqâ€™s racism case. The Indian viewers would also get to hear the voices hired by the Fox Sports. The commentators of Fox Sports for 2021-22 Ashes are: Adam Gilchrist â€“ ex-Australia wicket-keeper with 416 Test dismissals. Shane Warne â€“ 708 Test wickets for Australia. Mark Waugh â€“ ex-Australia batsman with 20 Test centuries. Kerry Oâ€™Keeffe â€“ former Australia spin bowler, 53 wickets in 24 Tests. Michael Vaughan â€“ ex-England captain, 5719 runs in 82 Tests. After the successful organization of the Syed Mushtaq Ali T20 Trophy last month, the BCCI is set to commence with its premier domestic 50-Over tournament- Vijay Hazare Trophy 2021-22 from December 8â€¦ The post Vijay Hazare Trophy 2021 22 All Teams Squads and Player List appeared first on The SportsRush.
newsArray.content: Vijay Hazare Trophy 2021 22 All Teams Squads and Player List: The Vijay Hazare Trophy 2021-22 is set to commence from December 8. After the successful organization of the Syed Mushtaq Ali T20 Trophy last month, the BCCI is set to commence with its premier domestic 50-Over tournament- Vijay Hazare Trophy 2021-22 from December 8 (Wednesday)- the schedule for which has been announced. A total of 38 teams would partake in the tournament from different zones such as Central Zone, East Zone, North Zone, South Zone, and West Zone. The teams are divided into different groups- Elite Group A, Elite Group B, Elite Group C, Elite Group D, Elite Group E, and Plate. The tournament would take place across nine cities namely Mumbai, Thane, Guwahati, Thiruvananthapuram, Mohali, Chandigarh, Rajkot, Ranchi and Jaipur. Gujarat Senior Men #Team for the Vijay Hazare Trophy 2021-22. newsArray.title: Harbhajan Singh Set To Join Support Staff Of Major IPL Franchise: Report
newsArray.description: Harbhajan Singh is expected to officially announce his retirement from competitive cricket some time next week and after that he will decide on one the offers he has got to be a part of the support...
newsArray.full_description: Former India off-spinner Harbhajan Singh will be seen in a different avatar during next year's Indian Premier League as a key member of the support staff in one of the high-profile franchises. The 41-year-old Harbhajan, who featured in a few matches during the first phase of last IPL for Kolkata Knight Riders, didn't play a game in the UAE leg of the league. Harbhajan is expected to officially announce his retirement from competitive cricket some time next week and after that he will decide on one the offers he has got to be a part of the support staff of at least a couple of franchises. "The role could be that of a consultant, mentor or part of the advisory group but the franchise with which he is talking are keen to use his vast experience. He will take active part in also helping the franchise decide on their auction picks," an IPL source privy to the development told PTI on conditions of anonymity. Harbhajan has always shown keen interest in grooming players and that was also his role in the later years with Mumbai Indians where he spent a fruitful decade. In fact, in the KKR last year, Harbhajan spent a lot of time guiding Varun Chakravarthy, who has been an integral part of the franchise for last the two seasons. Venkatesh Iyer, the find of last IPL, had earlier revealed that it was Harbhajan who had told him after a few net sessions that he will be a big hit in the league even before he had played a single game. In fact, during the last season, KKR's chief coach Brendon McCullum and skipper Eoin Morgan also paid heed to Harbhajan's advice in team selection matters. Promoted "Look, Harbhajan wanted to make a formal announcement of his retirement after the season is over. He has had extended talks with one of the franchises which has shown keen interest but he would like to talk about it only when the deal is formally inked," the source said. (This story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)

newsArray.title: Darren Gough lays out vision for Yorkshire in wake of Azeem Rafiq racism storm as Steve Harmison bids emotional farewell to talkSPORT colleague
creator: Josh Fordham
newsArray.description: Darren Gough laid out his vision for Yorkshire County Cricket Club after the talkSPORT legend was named managing director of cricket. The former England fast bowler takes over at the helm of the club during an incredibly turbulent time in its history. Their handling of Azeem Rafiqâ€™s experiences racism and harassment were widely criticised and [â€¦]
newsArray.content: Darren Gough laid out his vision for Yorkshire County Cricket Club after the talkSPORT legend was named managing director of cricket. The former England fast bowler takes over at the helm of the club during an incredibly turbulent time in its history. Goughie is the new managing director of Yorkshire County Cricket ClubGETTY Their handling of Azeem Rafiqâ€™s experiences racism and harassment were widely criticised and led to chairman Roger Hutton and chief executive Mark Arthur standing down. On Friday, 16 members of the coaching and medical staff were dismissed, including first-team coach Andrew Gale and director of cricket Martyn Moxon. Gough was under no illusions of the magnitude of the task before him, with his initial contract until the end of the 2022 season, but laid out what he wants to achieve. Rafiq gave emotional evidence before the DCMS committee about his experiences at Yorkshire The Drivetime host told talkSPORT following his return to Yorkshire: â€œWe have to face these issues, make positive actions. Thatâ€™s going to be the biggest thing we are looking at. â€œWe will be watched by the sporting world, not just in this country but around the world. We have to make a difference and I think that is obvious.Â  â€œWe have to take everyone at Yorkshire, no matter where they are from, on a journey, engage them, listen to them and I know this is such a big job because of that. I really, really do.Â  â€œWe do need to rebuild. We need to rebuild a culture and make Yorkshire County Cricket Club a better, more inclusive place. â€œThatâ€™s what it comes down to. Itâ€™s quite obvious and thatâ€™s what I see the vision for the club at this moment in time.â€ One of Goughieâ€™s first tasks will be to appoint a new coach and staff for the first team ahead of the new season. Gough knows he has a tough task ahead of him He added: â€œI know on social media and in some media that the favourite for the job is someone else at another club. â€œThat said person is a terrific coach, but we have to go through the right process. There will be an interview panel, there will be people interviewed. â€œThere are some magnificent coaches out there who are not in work at this moment in time, some are. â€œSome will fancy this challenge. For whoever takes it, it will be a difficult challenge. There will be a lot of changes and thatâ€™s why I took the job. â€œItâ€™s such a big rebuilding job. The club have come out and admitted it. Youâ€™ve heard me come out on talkSPORT and say that everything that went on with Azeem Rafiq and other members were handled badly. â€œThat was the biggest thing. It was handled badly and the club have recognised that. Itâ€™s so important.â€ Steve Harmison was delighted to see Gough land the job, but admitted he was devastated to see him leave talkSPORT. Harmison was sad to see his friend and talkSPORT colleague goThe Sun He said: â€œMy initial thoughts were â€˜are you out of your mind taking that on?â€™ That will be one of the toughest jobs not only in cricket but sport. â€œWeâ€™ve seen the headlines, but the more Iâ€™ve thought about it â€“ he is potentially the only person who could bring that club together.Â  â€œThe nature of who Darren is, the person he is, the affection he has for people and what people have got for him â€“ the first thing was to get the dressing room back on because a lot of players had run for the hills because of 16 members of staff had been finished. â€œHeâ€™s been given the job until 2022, but this is a five-year job, a 10-year job for Darren. He has to look at it that way. Yorkshire arenâ€™t coming back any time soon. â€œThey canâ€™t, itâ€™s not possible. â€œIâ€™m devastated heâ€™s leaving talkSPORT because heâ€™s worked 12/13 years to convince everybody not just that he knows a lot about football, but heâ€™s brilliant at the station. Iâ€™m devastated heâ€™s not going to be on here, but sometimes your heart leads you in a place you have to go. â€œThatâ€™s where Darren has gone and Iâ€™m over the moon for him. Iâ€™ll do anything for him if he ever needed a hand. â€œThere were countless numbers of messages to Darren yesterday that said if you ever need a hand, just pick the phone up. Thatâ€™s what Darren Gough does.â€

newsArray.title: Ravi Shastri Reveals "Lowest Point" As Team India Coach
newsArray.description: Former head coach of the Indian men's cricket team Ravi Shastri revealed the "lowest point" during his tenure.
newsArray.full_description: Ex-Team India all-rounder Ravi Shastri spoke honestly about the highs and lows during his tenure as the head coach of the Indian cricket team. Shastri talked about the Test series in Australia which was eventually won by Team India 2-1 despite being 1-0 down along with a list of injury setbacks. However, the pain was quite palpable when he spoke about India's sudden collapse in the second innings of the first Test at the Adelaide Oval which saw the visitor's get bowled out for 36 - their lowest total in Test cricket. In the interview with The Week , Shastri told how the entire contingent was "numb" and "in a state of shock" as the famed Indian batting line-up capitulated in only 21.2 overs. "See, the coach is in the firing line; there is no choice. That is the quirk of the job. You have to be ready from day one. I knew there would be no escape routes. The 36 all out was the lowest point. We had nine wickets in hand [overnight] and then we were bundled out for 36. All that had to be done was score 80-odd more runs [to be in the game]. We were all numb. We were in a state of shock for days. How could that have happened?" Shastri said. Shastri, however, seemed unperturbed by the criticism and said that he owed the debacle to himself and asked the Team to buckle up and perform better from then onwards. The results were there to be seen as India ended as the winners of the Border-Gavaskar Trophy. Promoted "It was not just me. I would be the first to put my hand up and say I was the one responsible, take the brickbats; there is no place to hide. I told the boys to focus on what they could do. The boys were unbelievable. One month after that 36 all out, on January 19, we had won the series. I am still thinking, how did that happen? I promise, as long as I live, people will talk about that series win," added Shastri. Pacer Josh Hazlewood was the wrecker-in-chief with a stupendous five-wicket haul while fellow fast bowler Pat Cummins also bagged four wickets. Australia clinched the first Test by eight wickets.
